title: How many U.S. states will the CDC report as having had a confirmed case of Wuhan coronavirus (2019-nCoV) as of 28 February 2020?
preds: It's possible we already have hit 12+ but may not know it until March

Updated from 98 to 99 as close of play draws near. No further news of new cases. Unlikely to update number of cases until US morning time. Remains a very small chance that they could announce more cases.
Current figures at 8 states. Required to have another set of cases announced by tomorrow, unlikely given testing times and current rate of spread.
Currently six, so it's almost impossible to reach twelve, even with community-related one from California last night

The Johns Hopkins site shows the location of 16 US cases (in 7 states), but lists 60. My estimate assumes the CDC isn't going to suddenly show the locations of the other 44 patients tomorrow before this question ends.
"The location of 20 confirmed cases is not available. Case numbers in states may change when patients are moved to different locations."
Unlikely that significant shifts from current levels in the next few days.
If I'm wrong, we have bigger problems than our Brier score.
Too late to see too dramatic of an increase in number of cases.
Finetuning probabilities as the question's deadline ends in 2 days.

The United States is known for taking extreme preventative measures in order to avoid the spread of an epidemic. As of today, there are still only 7 states that have confirmed cases of the Wuhan coronavirus as stated by the CDC. Because of that, there is now a 0% chance that the number of states is less than 5. The following statistics published by the CDC are influencing my prediction. As of today, there are still only 15 confirmed cases across these 7 states, but there are 52 pending cases that could potentially increase the number of states with a confirmed case if those pending are confirmed positive. There are 8 fewer pending cases from last week, and those 8 were confirmed negative over the course of the week. The chances of the rest that are pending to be negative is significantly more likely considering there are now 412 negative cases. The number of states and territories that have people under investigation is 42 and the total number of people who have been under investigation is 479. With these numbers I arrived at the following conclusion: the probability of positive cases is 0.031 (3.1%), which is down 0.01% from last week and the probability of negative cases is 0.86 (86.0%), which is up 3% from last week. That means that the probability of the 52 pending cases being positive and reaching to more than 11 states (5 more states than now) over the next couple of days is probable but significantly low. Since the probability is so low, I am saying that the number of states with positive cases is most likely to stay in the range it is now, unless the odds change and those pending end up positive then the number of states could jump up to the next range grouping (12-18). However, the extreme measures that the United States would take if over a quarter of its states were affected would make it very unlikely that the epidemic would get out of hand and affect more than 19 states.
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html
What if the CDC took down their USA map because of [_exaggerated_speculative_reason_]?
Anyone have a link to the CDC page that tracks which states?
The question resolves in three days, and the number of states has not significantly increased since last week.
Assuming a 2 week incubation time the number will shortly rise with exponential growth, but there only only 3 days left

Question resolves in 2.5 days and has been holding steady at 7 -8 states for several days now. An interesting development is that Johns Hopkins virus tracking website (link below) lists 36 US patients from the Diamond Princess cruiseship in "unassigned" locations, so they conceivably be anywhere in the US. There's a possibility that those 36 patients are in states that are already counting cases (WA, CA, AZ, TX, WI, IL, and NY), or they could be in NE, where news reports have said patients are being held (though the website doesn't show them).  (https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6)
Adjusting for time remaining in question
A lot can happen in 4 days... nothing is suggesting that 4 states will report cases in the next 4 days; but it is absolutely possible.

Pulling down only because of the time-frame. COVID-19 update: the USA has only tested 414 people for coronavirus and we have had a known defective kit problem. The outbreak is likely much worse than reported in the USA. #pandemic #COVID19 https://www.cnbc.com/…/only-three-us-states-can-test-for-co… https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html‬

"On Tuesday, Feb. 18, no coronavirus cases had been reported in Iran. On Sunday, the government announced 43 cases and eight deaths. Some 152 cases (and at least three deaths) were confirmed in Italy on Sunday, up from three cases on Thursday. The number of infected people in South Korea jumped to 763 (and six deaths) in just days."

It is challenging to find detail for each state. This page had a map showing 8 states affected by 23/2 - something to watch over next couple of days. https://www.earthfiles.com/2020/02/23/700-am-mtn-feb-19th-update-75216-covid-19-cases-2011-deaths-diamond-princess-quarantined-american-ship-passengers-were-evacuated-on-chartered-flight-with-14-americans-confirmed-positive-with/
Revising. Weighing "5 to 11" even heavier given there's only 4 days left and (surprisingly) there are still only 7 states with confirmed cases.
Unless there is a dramatic change in the next few days, it looks like it is holding steady between 5 and 11.
Previous forecasters have expressed a similar opinion. With time dwindling, paranoia and precautionary steps being taken, the upper reaches of state count are possible but less likely.

With 5 days to go, there are 8 states confirmed. So would need 4 more states to be declared in next 4 days. Last new state was on 13 Feb, and with awareness high - chances of 4 more states in 5 days seem extremely low. There is outside chance of new cluster, so non-zero.
Because they are already under-reporting. It will also be in cities like largely NY and DC because of diplomatic privileges to come and go unchecked.  This will include the President and staff.

Update:
I maintain the virus is more widespread than expected. As seen in Italy/Iran clusters can occur undetected until they grow enough for the small proportion of serious cases to become apparent. However given the limited testing regime I suspect the CDC will not confirm cases in nearly as many states as initially suspected.

Running my simulations again [1], assuming that Nebraska will be included, but taking into account that the number of states where testing can happen is limited. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/962894

I just noticed this on the CDC table listing "Confirmed cases in the United States" : * This table represents cases detected and tested in the United States through U.S. public health surveillance systems since January 21, 2020. It does not include people who returned to the U.S. via State Department-chartered flights.

There are currently eight states with confirmed cases: Arizona, California, Illinois, Nebraska, Massachusetts, Texas, Washington, and Wisconsin [1]. Note the addition of Nebraska, which is where recent evacuees from the Diamond Princess are hospitalized [2]. The last new state to confirm case(s) of COVID-19 was Texas on Feb. 13 [3]. As of yesterday, the CDC is confirming a total of 35 cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. [4]. [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2020/01/22/mapping-spread-new-coronavirus/?arc404=true
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/21/health/coronavirus-cases-usa.html
[3] https://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/15th-case-of-coronavirus-in-u-s-confirmed-in-texas-patient/2310541/
[4] https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html
This isn’t travel season in the US. Cases will pick up in other states as spring approaches.

Only 6 day left for this question. Seems to stay under control in the US. Nebraska is the 8th state now, and I think, that future cases will be brought there too (or to California or Texas as before). https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/21/health/coronavirus-cases-usa.html

I continue to be amazed that the US's detection/ quarantine/ containment strategies appear to be working. In the last 10 days, # US states with a COVID-19 case went from 6 to 7, much slower than I anticipated. Given there's only 6 days left in this challenge, I have to revise my forecasts down.  However, there is much room for pessimism (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/21/us-health-officials-prepare-for-coronavirus-outbreak-to-become-pandemic.html), so my forecasts will continue to reflect the coming spread, which I still think is inevitable.
At the moment CDC doesn´t report details, but you can find them here: https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/usa-coronavirus/
The difficulty with this prompt is the return of cruise passengers, which could drastically increase the number of states with confirmed cases.

It appears the CDC is no longer publishing a state by state list, just an overal number how they originated.
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html

While my guestimate of the number of cases among US citizens hasn't changed, it seems that the policy of quarantine of passengers from the cruise ship, and those staying in facilities in Japan (and elsewhere outside the US) will limit the number of states where we may expect to find cases by the 28th.

Time is rapidly running out. Also the CDC is attempting to keep potential incoming cases concentrated in a few states, almost all of which already have confirmed cases. So unless there's a sudden upsurge in new cases not easily traceable to Wuhan it appears very likely we'll end at 8-10 or so.
Anticipating between 10 and 15 states to report

If all passengers from the Diamond Princess should be quarantined in California and Texas with the infected being transferred elsewhere, this should add one state max to the existing 7. Only one week left for this Question, which still is an eternity considering a highly infectious Virus like corona. https://time.com/5785034/americans-covid-19-japan-cruise-ship/
I can't find any info on which states the new cases from Diamond Princess come from, but assuming these won't be counted as in those states and they are currently held on an air force base.

Updated just simply based on how little time there is left, there are only 52 cases currently pending diagnosis (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html)  the vast majority of which can be expected to come back negative. And the positive ones are very likely to be in the same states as those that already have cases. That being said, the same website does say that the 479 total cases investigated or currently under investigation since the beginning of the epidemic and that these came from 42 different states. So, theoretically, there is a possibility of it jumping up, but at this point, I think it is very unlikely.
Tightening my forecast as the remaining days are short.
The latest info I've seen has confirmed cases in 7 US states. It's a very large increase to go from 7 states to 12 states or more in a 2 or so week time period.
All the data suggests 5-11 at this point. Hundreds of American's got off the Westerdam cruise liner and most flew home.

20 feb (8 days to go)
15 positive cases in 7 states
412 PUI negative
52 PUI pending in 42 states and territories 15 of 427 cases is around 3%. Therefore, it’s unlikely that more than 4 cases will be positive. And even if 5 or 10 PUI are confirmed positive, they may not happen in a new state.
Update 20.2.2020. No new cases since 16 Feb 2020.

Updating to weight more to 5-11 band.
8 days to go and both negative and pending cases are dropping with no positives. My rather simple model says we end up with 8 or 9 states based on current outstanding cases. So chances of a just to 12 in the next 8 days is very low.
Sheets: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1AnjS1V_dHPvmIs8lA_9DwG_rZhiMzTZ0tLegT0DZcds/edit#gid=0

U.S. Should be able to keep the spread of this to a minimum.

from 27 jan to 18 feb, only 3 more states.
still PUI in 42 states

11 confirmed out of 178 tested (6%)
82 tests no results yet poss of further 5 cases confirmed, equals 16, but likely additional case over time period remaining, equals 17.
Strict control of incoming visitors from Asia by US government.

Adjusting based on current CDC data and number of days.  Currently, 7 states have cases.

The people most likely to be affected in the United states do not have access to the health care required for detection. As such, this will spread quietly and by the time the diagnosis happens, will have spread much farther than anticipated.
Urban context and climate will not propagate its spread.

PUI pending cases are down to 60. That yields 2 additional infected cases using the 4% infected rate I'm my earlier forecasts. There is zero chance to exceed 11 states. Besides they are not going to complete testing the all the 60 pending cases in 10 days.

The United States is known for taking extreme preventative measures in order to avoid the spread of an epidemic. As of today, the CDC has released that 7 states that have confirmed cases of the Wuhan coronavirus. Because of that, there is now a 0% chance that the number of states is less than 5. The following statistics published by the CDC are influencing my prediction. As of now, there are 15 confirmed cases across these 7 states, but there are 60 pending cases that could significantly increase the number of states with a confirmed case if those numbers are confirmed positive. The chances of those pending to be negative is significantly more likely considering there are 392 negative cases. The number of states and territories who have people under investigation is 42 and the total number of people who have been under investigation is 467. With these numbers I arrived at the following conclusion: the probability of positive cases is 0.032 (3.2%) and the probability of negative cases is 0.839 (83.9%). That means that the probability of the 60 cases being positive and reaching to more than 11 states (5 more states than now) over the next two weeks is probable but significantly low. Since the probability is so low, I am saying that the number of states with positive cases is likely to stay in the range it is now, unless the odds change and those pending end up positive then the number of states could jump up to the next range grouping (12-18). However, the extreme measures that the United States would take if over a quarter of its states were affected would make it very unlikely that the epidemic would get out of hand and affect more than 19 states.

Proceedures appear to have a postive impact on containment. With only 11 days left in the forecast period i'll tighten the numbers. Let us hope procedures continue to work and the 14 day period proves adequate.

There are currently seven states with confirmed cases of the Wuhan Coronavirus. However, due to increasing outbreaks, the chances of states with major international travel between China and the United States are more likely to be exposed to the Coronavirus. These states include the non-infected New York, Nevada, and Georgia. Given the growth of the Coronavirus in countries in Europe, in Australia, and northern Africa, airports with flights to those countries must be considered as well.

As of today, according to the CDC, there are seven states with confirmed cases: Arizona, California, Illinois, Massachusetts, Texas, Washington, and Wisconsin [1]. The most recent confirmed case in the U.S. occurred four days ago and the total number of confirmed cases in the U.S. has also remained unchanged at fifteen since four days ago [2]. Bimodal as either containment will begin to work and only a few other states affected, or it starts to properly spread from new hubs such as singapore, albeit with only a short timescale in which to do so. 42 states have Patients under observation, a conservative 25% of those may be infected getting to 10 states.

Forgot to update with new probabilities

The most recent confirmed case in the U.S. was three days ago in Texas. That brought us to a total of seven states with confirmed cases: Arizona, California, Illinois, Massachusetts, Texas, Washington, and Wisconsin [1, 2]. Modelling by Johns Hopkins shows that there are at least nine other states (Hawaii, Colorado, Nevada, New York, Louisiana, Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, and Michigan) + the District of Columbia (which counts for this question) where the risk of COVID-19 importation is high [3]. A relevant update is that hundreds of Americans are being evacuated from a cruise ship that is docked in Japan where forty-four Americans have already tested positive for the virus [4]. Upon arrival in the U.S., they will be quarantined for two weeks at military bases in Texas and California [4]. It is very likely that there will be confirmed cases among these hundreds of evacuated Americans, but any such confirmed cases will not be relevant for this question since California and Texas are already two of the seven U.S. states with confirmed cases.  [1] https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html
[2] https://www.cbsnews.com/news/coronavirus-united-states-us-cities-confirmed-cases-wuhan-china-symptoms/
[3] https://systems.jhu.edu/research/public-health/ncov-model-2/
[4] https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/coronavirus-china-updates/2020/02/16/616e9a74-4f6d-11ea-bf44-f5043eb3918a_story.html

As of 2/15, there are 15 confirmed COVID-19 cases in the USA across 7 states. The first USA case was confirmed on 1/21 in Washington state. In the 25 days since then, 14 more cases in 6 more states were confirmed. If this trend continues, in 13 more days there will be cases in approximately 3.79 more states or almost 11 total. This makes this forecast challenging. There are still 81 cases pending in the USA but 347 previously pending people have already tested negative. Of all the suspected cases in the USA only 4.14% have been confirmed.  I believe the trend is unlikely to continue as the outbreak around the world seems to be more and more under control every day.  Additionally, the CDC has implemented screenings at airports and quarantines of suspected cases around the country. Consequently, I believe it is most likely that no more than 11 states will record cases by 2/28. There is a chance though that more could see cases. 
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/usa-coronavirus/
https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6

There are currently 7 confirmed states plus another likely exposure in Hawaii, therefore the number of states cannot be less than 5. There have been 362 resolved PUIs (Person Under Investigation), of whom 15 tested positive. This yields a 4% rate of positive cases per PUI. There are still 81 pending PUI cases. If 4% of those are positive there will be 3 new cases. There have been 15 cases in 24 days since the first confirmed American case, yielding a rate of 0.625 cases per day. Extrapolating that to February 28th gives us 8 new cases. There have been 15 cases in 7 states, giving us 2 cases per state. If there are 3-8 new cases, there will likely be 1-4 more states with confirmed coronavirus cases. This yields a range of 8-11 states, plus the possibility of an additional case in Hawaii, which would push the sum to 12.
Any flu like virus is hard to contain.
5 to 11 looks great till I think about cruise ships docked in N across from NYC. Lot of states in a small area there.

Latest update from CDC [1].  81 pending PUI (up from 68 early on 10 Feb).  Using 4% as the infected rate (from my earlier analysis [3]) produces 3.2 additional infected cases.   Since my original analysis [2], there were 4 additional infected cases and 2 additional states.  Using this ratio to the projected 3 additional cases will add another 1.6 (lets round it to 2) states.  This will produce a total of 2+7=9 states.  For a more extreme case with all 3 infected cases come from different states, this only results in 7+3=10 states.   It is highly likely that the number of states goes beyond 11. [1] https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/962308
[3]  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/965165

I'm not sure if I missed the data last time at CDC, but they show PUI by "positive", "negative", and "pending".
This gives us a view of the percent tested that come back positive. 
I've done a quick approach to this here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1AnjS1V_dHPvmIs8lA_9DwG_rZhiMzTZ0tLegT0DZcds/edit?usp=sharing Essentially looking at the percent of those tested that come back positive. This tells us how many new positive cases are likely. Then we just work out the probability of those cases being in a new state*. Which ends up at 9.8. It's a simple, slightly hacky approach. But I'm going with it! * A big consideration though is the likelihood that a positive is in an existing state, because it was transmitted locally. I'm not sure how many US cases are "imported" vs. transmitted locally, but assuming that all are "imported" here.
I read 7 confirmed states already. But many of the remaining states do not have easily reached populations.

There are 7 states at present with confirmed cases and 42 states with PUI.  Tat being said, it will be a matter of waiting out the various quarantines and/or tests results.  Additionally, there was a problem with the initial test kits sent out.  This increases a risk of infections from inappropriately cleared patients.
Already in 7 states. Not sure all Americans will present if they lack healthcare especially say Chinese labourers so it may spread more and Americans like to travel about.
there have been more exposures than we know and evidence of infection are just now coming to light
Only because of varying places of quarantine
It has just started to spread.

A new case was confirmed today in Texas, which brings us to a total of seven states with confirmed cases: Arizona, California, Illinois, Massachusetts, Texas, Washington, and Wisconsin [1, 2].  Modelling by Johns Hopkins shows that there are at least nine other states (Hawaii, Colorado, Nevada, New York, Louisiana, Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, and Michigan) + the District of Columbia (which counts for this question) where the risk of COVID-19 importation is high [3]. Also, keep in mind that there is probably a lag of at least a few days in COVID-19 case detection since there have been issues with the testing kits that the CDC has recently distributed [4, 5] - there may be more states that will be confirmed to have cases once this backlog is addressed. I'm betting that we are likely to add 4 more based on heavy air traffic: HI, GA, NY, NJ at a minimum That would be 11.

7 States had cases already. Given the seemingly long incubation period, and the yet unconfirmed possibility for asymptomatic transmission, it is reasonable to assess that this number will increase further. The spread is limited mainly through contract tracing and prevention, not severe containment. If indeed the incubation period could be of up to 24 days, when it was estimated to be of maximum 14 days only last week, then a few spreaders may have slipped through the cracks.

New article in NYT: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/12/health/coronavirus-cases-china.html The new numbers (which are impacted by a faster method of identifying infected people) are alarming. Anecdotes continue to emerge that demonstrate the virus' contagiousness, even before the victim shows any signs. Bottom line, there seem to be a lot more cases out there than we know.  
Decreasing the "6 to 11" to 10%. 
Increasing the "12 to 18" to 70%. Given there are 6 US states with confirmed cases, doubling that number in the next 12 days seems highly likely. 
Increasing "19 to 25" for all reasons listed in article and summarized above.
American medical system is more stronger and better.

- Currently 6 states with infections
- Per the CDC, in the US so far: 347 negative tests and 14 positive tests (so, about 4% of tests are coming back positive). Also, presently 66 specimens in testing, which will likely yield at least one more infection. 
- News today that the virus may spread through pipes, so contagion may be easier than normal.
- News today that a positive patient was inadvertently released from quarantine at Miramar Air Station in CA, indicating that symptoms may be very hard to detect initially. 
- ***News today from top CDC official that US should prepare for virus to "take a foothold" in the US*** 
- All above points to a steady increase in US cases over next 2 weeks.

6 states are confirmed.

I'm keeping this relatively simple - assume 10% of states with PUI are confirmed by Feb 28 = 11.
Outlier of >25 is not impossible, so 2%. 19-25 is in the realm of possibility, so 6%. Then split the difference around 11 = 46% on 5-11 and 12-18.

CDC as of Feb 12 still shows only 6 states, and 60 cases pending from a total of 41 locales. The US appears to have been very fortunate so far.

With time winding down on this forecast window, there are reported cases in 6 US states. More cases may be reported in the next two weeks, but travel restrictions, awareness/paranoia, and global response makes for an unlikely scenario where state count doubles.

We're still at six states - this figure has not changed since Feb. 7. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html

According to the CDC in the previous 20 days a total of 12 of 398 U.S. citizens under monitoring in five states have reported positive symptoms. Another 68 are pending results. The remainder have tested negative. According to the World Health Organization's 10 February SITREP, 3,085 new cases have been confirmed globally in the last 24 hours - only 12 of those new cases were outside of China, with no new countries reporting any new cases within the last 24 hours, and no new countries reporting any new cases over the last six days.  This suggests that the bulk of new cases remain confined to China, and travel restrictions (along with other measures) instituted by many countries around the world, including the U.S., appear to be effective in limiting the further spread of the virus. Based on this, I believe it is highly likely that only a few new cases will appear in the U.S. over the next 18 days, likely in states with large capacity airports or seaports with high volumes of international travel, potentially arising only in 2-3 new states by 28 February 2020 (possibly New York, Texas, and Florida, if I had to guess) for a total of around eight total states by end of month.

About 350 Americans arrived Wednesday on government-arranged flights from China. They will be quarantined at military bases for 14 days.

Jordan and Bosman (2020) Feb. 5, stated that:
\ LOS ANGELES — Americans evacuated from Hubei province in China arrived in California on government-arranged planes on Wednesday morning, and were greeted with applause by waiting medical personnel. They received health screenings, were warned to stay six feet away from the other families and were asked not to let children share toys. Eventually, bleary-eyed from an 11-hour flight, they fell asleep in their new temporary homes on military bases. The number of American evacuees from China under federal quarantine for the deadly coronavirus more than doubled on Wednesday with the arrival of two new planeloads of people. The new group of about 350, mostly American citizens, will be held at Travis Air Force Base in Fairfield, Calif., and at Marine Corps Air Station Miramar in San Diego for 14 days, believed to be the maximum time it takes a person to become ill after being exposed to the coronavirus (Para 1-3).

Finally I made up my mind about the probabilities. But first let me explain how I compute this. There are two factors to consider: (1) How many cases there will be by 28th of February, (2) What will be the distribution between different states. (1) How many cases there will be by 28th of February? For that we have to estimate how quickly this will spread. If this is fully contained, there will be only a few more scattered cases, maybe 5 more in a very optimistic scenario. If this is not contained then we could expect the number of cases to double every week or so (owing to the incubation period and the infamous R0 parameter which we have now all heard about). In this latter case the expectation would be about 80 new cases by the end of February. The distribution is log-normal, owing to the exponential nature of the propagation of a new virus at the beginning. The problem is which is the mean and which is the variance: 1.a) I will assume that a 1 sigma variation corresponds to a doubling/halfing of the number of cases. That is, if the expected number of cases is N, then there is a 68% probability of having N/2 to 2N cases and a 98% probability of N/4 to 4N cases. 1.b) There will be an optimistic scenario in which we would expect the probability to peak at 10 new cases from now till 28th of February. 1.c) There will be a pessimistic scenario in which we would expect the probability to peak at 20 new cases from now till 28th of February. 2) What is the distribution of cases among states? Here I will use two models: 2.a) In model a we assume that if there is a new cases, the probability of appearing in state X is equal to the percentage of the population living in this state (respective to the 50+1 states considered in the question). 2.b) In model  b we assume that new cases cluster over old cases: the probability of appearing in state X is equal to the percentage of population living in this state times the current number of cases in said state plus one. Model a could roughly correspond to the virus coming from outside, while model b could correspond to having small outbreaks clustered around previous cases. By the way, model a when feed with the 11 cases we already have, gives a 98% probability for the between 5 and 11 bucket, which gives me confidence in the fact that this model might have some merits to it. Now, let's crunch the numbers and fill the buckets (with the initial condition that there already are 11 cases in 5 different states): a+a) Optimistic + model a gives 0, 51, 39, 10, 0 
a+b) Optimistic + model b gives 0, 89, 11, 0, 0 b+a) Pessimistic + model a gives 0, 17, 45, 37, 0
b+b) Pessimistic + model b gives 0, 66, 33, 1, 0 Now we have to average these probabilities. For that I do as follows: Optimistic: 2/3 of model a probabilities + 1/3 of model b probabilities (imported cases expected to be more important than home-grown cases):  0, 64, 30, 6, 0 Pessimistic: 1/3 of model a probabilities + 2/3 of model b probabilities (imported cases expected to be less important than home-grown cases):  0, 50, 37, 13, 0 As we can see, the probabilities now look similar in both cases. By averaging the two scenarios we arrive at 0, 57, 34, 9, 0 (my current answer). Now in the following days we will be able to correct the distribution as we have the information of how the number of cases are evolving.

CDC has a daily update on the Wuhan coronavirus [1].  The information on People Under Investigation (PUI) includes number of confirmed cases, number of negative tests and number of pending cases.  This forecast is based on this CDC information. As of 3 February, the total PUI is 260, out of which 11 are confirmed, 167 negative and 82 pending.  That means out of the 178 PUI already tested, 6.2% are confirmed and 93.8% are negative.  If you assume these percentages hold for the 82 pending cases, this would produce 5 positive and 77 negative additional cases. Out of the 178 tested, 11 confirmed cases came from 5 states.  Using this ratio of 11 to 178, the 82 pending cases will yield 2 additional states, making a total of 7 states with confirmed cases.   I understand that these 2 additional states may coincide with the 5 existing states.  However, 36 different states have PUI [1].  So the additional 2 states are not that far fetched.   [1]  https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html

Earlier today, health officials in Massachusetts confirmed their state's first case of 2019-nCoV [1]. This brings the total number of states with confirmed cases to five.  New York City has just announced a possible case [2,3] that will very likely be confirmed by the CDC within a few days. This individual "had recently traveled from China & presented with fever and cough or shortness of breath without another common cause, like influenza and other cold viruses, identified on testing." [4] We will know for sure whether or not this individual has 2019-nCoV within 36-48 hours, but I think it's more likely than not that this will end up being confirmed. In addition to the five states (California, Washington, Arizona, Illinois, Massachusetts) with confirmed cases and one state (New York) that will almost certainly have a confirmed case, modelling by Johns Hopkins shows that there are at least nine other states (Hawaii, Colorado, Nevada, Texas, Louisiana, Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, and Michigan) + the District of Columbia (which counts for this question) where the risk of 2019-nCoV importation is high [5]. DR. FAUCI: In accordance with the declaration, beginning at 5:00 p.m., Eastern Standard Time; Sunday, February the 2nd, the United States government will implement temporary measures to increase our abilities to detect and contain the coronavirus proactively and aggressively.  Any U.S. citizen returning to the United States who has been in Hubei Province in the previous 14 days will be subject to up to 14 days of mandatory quarantine to ensure they are they are provided proper medical care and health screening. To be clear, this applies only to U.S. citizens who have been in Hubei Province in the past 14 days prior to their attempted entry into the United States. Any U.S. citizen returning to the United States who has been in the rest of Mainland China within the previous 14 days will undergo proactive entry health screening at a select number of ports of entry and up to 14 days of monitored self-quarantine to ensure they’ve not contracted the virus and do not pose a public health risk. Additionally, the President has signed a presidential proclamation, using his authority pursuant to Section 212(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, temporarily suspending the entry into the United States of foreign nationals who pose a risk of transmitting the 2019 novel coronavirus. As a result, foreign nationals, other than immediate family of U.S. citizens and permanent residents, who have traveled in China within the last 14 days will be denied entry into the United States for this time. https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/press-briefing-members-presidents-coronavirus-task-force/

The number of states with potential infections is now 36, but only 4 are with positive results. Should we go for majority of states to end up on the final list, especially with number of PUI standing at 160? Not quite, IMHO. Firstly, please notice that the number of positive cases stayed the same  (5) while the number of negative samples more than doubled within 2 days- from 32 (1/27/10) to 68 (1/29/20). Positive rate fell more than half and we expect it may fall further until it reaches a plateau. Most negatives come because of the scare – better overdo  screening than not. Next. Not all states are created equal. 
4 states are already on the list – California, Illinois, Arizona and Washington – have 48% of the Chinese immigrants of the whole USA (based on Census 2010 and Wikipedia - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Americans). I use relative numbers of the Chinese as a proxy for probability estimates to end up on the final list - the more Chinese in the state, the higher probability of travelers coming from China to the state. Of course, business and tourism travel of all other people can be significant factor as well. The probabilities of the  latter roughly correlate with overall populations in the state. We can use numbers of American Chinese for that too for simplicity as we do not know exact contributions for these factors.  Back to our model. Add to the 4 already on the list another state (especially if we add NY) and the first bucket is quite possible as new cases will have more than 50% probability to stay in the 1st bucket (with NY – 65%).  The 2nd bucket. If it is comprised of the 8 other states with largest Chinese American populations, it would have 36% for new cases to end up there. Of course, this is not random selection and if by chance NY is not in this bucket, probability is even lower. The other buckets will be filled even with lower probabilities.  Of course, the number of states is cumulative and with endless time all states can be hit. But time is not endless – the time frame is just one month. Too little information to add cumulative effect. The new cases have more than 50% stay in the 1st bucket, but can be spilled into the 2nd (and 3rd, but the time is too short). So, I expect only 2 first buckets to be in play – depending on the number of new cases (which will be also limited due to all travel restrictions in place). Long rambling post with big holes, I know. I find this question the hardest to structure in my mind. First, there are going to be a lot of cases. However it seems  possible that transmission in the US may be stopped on slowed significantly compared to that in China. (or not). So we have to factor a different dynamic in the US into the analysis. I'm assuming that most cases in the US will come from people entering from China in the next month. Most of those people will be coming through major airports and will be screened. So the vast majority of cases will be in a few transportation hubs with a lot of flights to/from Asia: California, Washington, Hawaii, Illinois, New York, Georgia, Florida, Texas.  A few will get through. So i"m going to start with estimate >11.
AUstralia and Now the US have diverted there relief flights from WooHan to quarantine. That should slow the spread
Suspect but not confirmed cases in 28 states according to CNBC so consider the source.

This one is tricky as the threshold is so low - just one case per state is enough. But the reason we have this question is overall awareness of the new emerging infection and preventive measures for it. I'd think the probability to get on the list at least partially correlates with numbers of Chinese immigrants (of course, China is a big country and infection comes from its South East provinces). That makes sense for  California (1st biggest), Illinois and Washington (6th and 7th, respectively). New York, New Jersey, Texas, Massachusetts are not on the list, but we may expect some of them appear there. Arizona is on the list, but does not have large numbers of the immigrants of the Chinese origin. I'd bet NY would be on the list at some point. But does it happen in a month?
There are four right now with 5 confirmed cases but 73 pending and that is likely to grow as they brink back more citizens from China. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-in-us.html

The way situation is getting serious, there maybe already few people spread across few States in US. It is unlikely in that case that those people will be from same four States as people travel all the time. So, four cases in about 2-3 weeks makes easy to project 3-4 more States at the end of the month of February.
